prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: The Panel typically implements remand by entry of a conditional remand order. The Panel Rules specifically provide for entry of such an order.[1] The Panel uses this procedure when the transferee court advises the Panel that the cases are ready for trial and should therefore be remanded, or if the Panel becomes aware of that fact through other means.[2] Remand proceedings may also be initiated by a party by a motion for remand.[3]

A conditional remand order, although entered sua sponte, does not indicate any predilection on the part of the Panel to order remand. The conditional remand order is procedurally similar to the conditional transfer order used to facilitate the efficient handling of matters before the Panel while providing notice to all interested parties of the proceedings.[4]

Consideration of remand may be initiated by any of three means: motion of any party, suggestion of the transferee court, or on the Panel's own initiative.[5] Of these, suggestion of remand by the transferee court is both the most common and the most likely to result in remand being ordered.[6] The Rules add an additional requirement for a party seeking remand by motion. Panel Rule 10.3(a)(i) requires that a motion for remand be accompanied by an affidavit stating that all common discovery and other pretrial proceedings are complete and that orders of the transferee court have been complied with. A copy of a final pretrial order, if one has been entered, must also be submitted.

A party seeking remand must convince the Panel that remand is appropriate. If all pretrial proceedings have not been completed and the cases certified “ready for trial” by the transferee court, remand is unlikely. The Panel has stated:

We remand an action prior to the completion of pretrial proceedings only upon a showing of good cause. Defendants have not persuaded us that remand at this time would promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.[7]

The most effective evidence of completion of pretrial proceedings is a transferee court's formal notice of suggestion of remand. This notice of suggestion essentially advises the Panel (and the litigants) that the judge views his or her mission as transferee judge over.[8] This notice is not merely a means of starting remand proceedings, but is given great weight by the Panel on the merits of remand.[9] The absence of such a notice creates a difficult burden for the party seeking remand to overcome.[10] In one decision the Panel observed:

Absent a notice of suggestion of remand from the transferee judge to the Panel, any party advocating remand before the Panel bears a strong burden of persuasion. We rule that movants have not met that burden here and that the motion for remand is premature.[11]

The Panel also places great weight on the presence of a notice of suggestion of remand by the transferee judge. The Panel has stated that it is “greatly influenced by the transferee judge's suggestion that remand of the action is appropriate.”[12] A party opposing remand in face of the transferee judge's suggestion that all coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings are completed and remand is appropriate has an especially difficult burden to carry.[13] Similarly, seeking remand from the Panel where the transferee judge has considered the issue and declined to suggest remand has a distinctly uphill fight.[14]

In one case the Panel specifically remanded 83 cases where the transferee court had suggested remand and denied motions to transfer six other actions where the transferee court had not suggested remand.[15]

Remand does not give the Panel an opportunity to review or control the progress of the transferred cases. The Panel does not order any substantive relief as part of the remand order. Similarly, the remand order cannot be conditioned on the parties taking some further action. For example, the Panel in one case refused to order payment of fees to liaison counsel as a part of a remand order or to condition entry of a remand order on payment of fees to liaison counsel.[16]

The Panel may order remand even if it would subject a party to the burden of having to extricate itself from numerous cases rather than just one consolidated case. In one case the Panel ordered remand despite the objections of a defendant that had obtained summary judgment dismissing it from the action. The defendant had not obtained the entry of judgment, and the Panel remand decision required it to obtain a separate judgment in each of the original transferee courts.[17]
Remand does not require that all pretrial proceedings have been completed in every action. The Panel has noted:

It is not contemplated that a Section 1407 transferee judge will necessarily complete all pretrial proceedings in all actions transferred and assigned to him by the Panel, but rather that the transferee judge in his discretion will conduct the common pretrial proceedings with respect to the actions and any additional pretrial proceedings as he deems otherwise appropriate.[18]

Remand may be appropriate where the transferee court orders bifurcated proceedings and the discovery and trial on the common issues is complete.[19] The Panel has also ruled that remand is not affected by an automatic stay under the bankruptcy law, and has ordered remand despite the stay.[20]

One factor that may favor remand of an action or all actions is the lack of opposition of any party to remand. This is a factor relied on by the Panel in other decisions made by it[21] and it has been cited by the Panel at the time of remand as well.[22]

The decision on when to suggest remand is essentially one of managerial discretion. Remand is not appropriate if there is more to be done on the cases as a group. Where all pretrial proceedings are concluded, or where the remaining proceedings relate to individual cases and issues rather than to the entire docket or to groups of cases, remand should be considered.[23]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
